legislation.statute: The current RPS was enacted in 2007 through creation of Illinois Power Agency (IPA). The IPA's purpose was to develop electricity procurement plans for renewable power. The legislation more specifically: 75% (equal to 18.75% total power sales in 2025) wind power annually for IOUs, and 60% for ARES by 2020; The 6% (equating to 1.5% of total retail sales) annual solar carve out ramps up for IOUs in 2013, and in 2016 for ARES., 1% carve out for distributed generation. Renewable generation limited to “cost-effective” resources. Renewable energy may be bundled with RECs. In 2011, anaerobic digestion was added to eligible resources. A second efficiency portfolio standard exists.

rps_tech_details.name: Eligible Technologies
rps_tech_details.description: Solar Thermal Electric, Photovoltaics, Landfill Gas, Wind, Biomass, Hydroelectric, Anaerobic Digestion, Biodiesel

rps_tech_details.name: Geographic Eligibility
rps_tech_details.description: (Only IOUs) Through 2011: in-state (if insufficient cost-effective resources, can procure from adjoining states, or regions). After 2011: equal preference to in- and out-of-state.

rps_tech_details.name: Technology Requirements
rps_tech_details.description: Wind (IOUs) - 75% of annual Req., Wind (ARES) - 60% of annual req., PV (all) - 6% of annual req., Dist. gen. (IOUs) - 1% of annual req.

rps_tech_details.name: Sectors
rps_tech_details.description: Investor-Owned Utilities, Retail Suppliers. Municipal electric companies and Electric Cooperative exempt from RPS.

rps_tech_details.name: Non-compliance Penalty
rps_tech_details.description: For Com-Ed: $0.946/MWh (for hourly customer loads). For Ameren: $0.973/MWh

legislation.carveouts: Illinois' wind technology requirement comprises the majority of its RPS goals. The chart below is a breakdown for the primary RPS for IOUs. It remains consistent at 75% of the standard each year.
legislation.cost_cap_details: Renewable energy procurement is limited to cost-effective resources. The cost cap is set at 'the greater of an additional 0.5% of the amount paid per kWh during the year ending in 2010, or 2% of the amount paid per kWh during the year ending May, 2007.' If exceeded, RPS requirements are placed under a 'freeze.' In addition, a second cost-effectiveness test: cost of procurement of renewable energy must not exceed benchmarks based on market prices for renewable energy in the region (determined by the IPA). overview: 25% of the state's energy consumption must be from renewable sources by 2025
Explicit cost cap at 2 percent of sales
Two separate state RPS schedules (primary and secondary)
snapshot.policy_trajectory: Most states define a pathway to 'ramp-up' the amount of renewable energy that must be sold. This chart allows you to compare your state's policy pathway to its neighbors. California's pathway is red. Click on another state to learn more about their RPS.
snapshot.summary: Illinois's Renewable Portfolio Standard (RPS) establishes a minimum amount of renewable energy that must be sold by the state's electricity providers. This page identifies and describes the features of the RPS and how they work together to define the minimum amount of renewable energy that will be sold in Illinois.
